video.title: Kotlin Course - Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn the Kotlin programming language in this introduction to Kotlin. Kotlin is a general purpose, open source, statically typed “pragmatic” programming language. It is used for many things, including Android development.

🎥Course developed by Nate Ebel. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVysWoMPvvHQMEJvRkslbAQ

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:50) Create Your First Kotlin Project
⌨️ (0:04:23) Hello World
⌨️ (0:06:33) Working With Variables
⌨️ (0:11:04) Type System
⌨️ (0:15:00) Basic Control Flow
⌨️ (0:21:31) Basic Kotlin Functions
⌨️ (0:27:12) Function Parameters
⌨️ (0:32:52) Arrays
⌨️ (0:35:28) Iterating with forEach
⌨️ (0:41:17) Lists
⌨️ (0:42:47) Maps
⌨️ (0:45:05) Mutable vs Immutable Collections
⌨️ (0:49:24) Vararg Parameters
⌨️ (0:54:21) Named Arguments
⌨️ (0:56:26) Default Parameter Values
⌨️ (1:00:27) Create A Simple Class
⌨️ (1:03:35) Adding Class Properties
⌨️ (1:05:15) Class Init Block
⌨️ (1:06:40) Accessing Class Properties
⌨️ (1:07:32) Primary Constructor Properties
⌨️ (1:08:17) Secondary Constructors
⌨️ (1:09:50) Working With Multiple Init Blocks
⌨️ (1:11:30) Default Property Values
⌨️ (1:11:59) Properties With Custom Getters/Setters
⌨️ (1:16:52) Class Methods
⌨️ (1:20:12) Visibility Modifiers - Public/Private/Protected/Public
⌨️ (1:22:30) Interfaces
⌨️ (1:24:21) Abstract Classes
⌨️ (1:26:13) Implementing An Interface
⌨️ (1:26:35) Overriding Methods
⌨️ (1:28:30) Default Interface Methods
⌨️ (1:29:30) Interface Properties
⌨️ (1:31:40) Implementing Multiple Interfaces
⌨️ (1:32:57) Type Checking And Smart Casts
⌨️ (1:36:18) Inheritance
⌨️ (1:43:07) Object Expressions
⌨️ (1:45:06) Companion Objects
⌨️ (1:49:51) Object Declarations
⌨️ (1:52:41) Enum Classes
⌨️ (1:58:16) Sealed Classes
⌨️ (2:00:07) Data Classes
⌨️ (2:12:25) Extension Functions/Properties
⌨️ (2:16:40) Higher-Order Functions
⌨️ (2:29:07) Using The Kotlin Standard Library
⌨️ (2:00:07) Data Classes

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
Use equal sign '=' instead of colon ':' for named argument, or use positional argument:
sayHello(greeting = "hi", interestingThings) _// named_
sayHello("hi", interestingThings) _// positional_

*sayHello(greeting: "hi", interestingThings)* is not a valid Kotlin code, "greeting:" is added by the text editor and is not part of the actual code (you can see it uses different font for "greeting:" at 48:57).

topLevelComment.author: Astaghfirullahalzim Astaghfirullahalzim
topLevelComment.text:
@2:00:58
why did you said the data class was immutable
but now you can change it .
Initially, you set the value of entity1 with "id" and "name"
and then when assigning to entity2, you changed entity1 object by accessing "copy()" constructor and changed the "name" value
is immutable in kotlin means different thing than java?

replies.author: Astaghfirullahalzim Astaghfirullahalzim
replies.text: @1:00:30 for class

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: Good question.  The copy() constructor doesn't change the instance on which it's called, but instead creates a brand new instance.  So in your example, entity1 is not changing.  entity2 is a copy entity1, but with specific values updated.  So the immutability is at the instance level.  Once created, we can't change the values of an object, but we can copy/modify them when we need to update the state.

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: Kotlin supports top-level functions; meaning we can have functions that are not associated with any enclosing class.  This is a difference from Java.  So if we have a top-level function, then no, we don't need any class to invoke the function.  If we define a method; meaning a function on a class, then we still need an instance of that class to invoke the function.

topLevelComment.author: Fazal Jarral
topLevelComment.text: why was the "object" keyword used?

replies.author: Fazal Jarral
replies.text: @goobar thank you  , started learning tornadoFX after watching your series.

replies.author: goobar
replies.text:
`object` is used in a few different ways in Kotlin.  It can be used as an object declaration to define a class as a Singleton.  It can be used as an object expression to create an anonymous inner class.  Or, it can be used as a companion object to somewhat replcate static methods on a class

I tend to use `object` a lot when defining sealed classes.  If a sealed class type only needs a single instance in your application (likely because it takes no parameters) then using an object declaration is a nice way to ensure there's only ever a single instance of that class

topLevelComment.author: CrazyJäger
topLevelComment.text:
I have watched many “tutorials” explaining programming languages. By far, yours is not only an actual tutorial, but a very good one indeed! 
It has all the core values a good tutorial must have: starts from the basic elements and slowly makes its way up the ladder into more complex functionality, it is slowly and carefully explained with simple examples (I have seen people using frameworks for a graphic user interface just for a hello world in a new language...) and shows the result for both the valid cases and invalid cases as well as ways to tackle common problems that may appear.

I had zero knowledge about Kotlin walking into this tutorial and I have quite a good idea of how it works now by only watching the video (when I start actually writing code, this will be consolidated) also thanks for all the Java analogies, they really helped understanding some of the last concepts.

11/10 on this tutorial, 11/10!

topLevelComment.text:
At 01:30:55 timestamp


for class BasicInfoProvider
Shouldn't it be 


override fun providerInfo: String
get() = field
set(value)  {
     field = "BasicInfoProvider"
 }

since getter is used to getter(get()) the field and setter(set()) is used to set the field?

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: In that example, providerInfo isn't a function, it's a read-only property.  So, it actually doesn't have a generated setter.  So to implement it's value, we can override the getter to specify what should be returned any time a caller accesses the getter

topLevelComment.author: Walter Cisneros
topLevelComment.text: Hi, I'm kind of halfway but I really don't get this Underscore thing, (1:05:00) I've read some over the internet and says it is for unused parameters but in what sense? thanks!

replies.author: goobar
replies.text:
If you're using a lambda (which is a function that takes 0..N arguments) then if any of the arguments aren't going to be needed for the implementation of that function, you can use an underscore rather than name the argument.  The idea is to reduce visual noise by only naming arguments that are relevant.  


Let's say we have this function:
fun printUserInfo(firstName: String, lastName: String, formater: (String, String) -> String) {
    println(formater(firstName, lastName))
}


As one of its parameters, it takes a function with two String parameters


We could call this printUserInfo function like this and name the two arguments within the lambda as "first" and "last"
printUserInfo("peter", "parker") { first, last ->
        "$first $last"
    }


However, if we only wanted to format the string using the first parameter, we could replace "last" with an underscore
printUserInfo("peter", "parker") { first, _ ->
        "$first"
    }


Does that help?

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: @Que_Rico Learning a language on its own likely won't land you a job.  I think it's more helpful to think about what you can build with a language.  Learning Kotlin can enable you to build a variety of things that likely have different demand in the job market.   If you learn to build Android apps with Kotlin there are many jobs out there.  Writing backend code with Kotlin could help find a job as well.  I'd encourage you to think of what types of projects you want to work on, then determine if Kotlin is a viable tool for that project.  If it is, and there's a demand for that work in the job market, then Kotlin would definitely be a positive step towards landing a job.

topLevelComment.author: Ruxa A
topLevelComment.text: How is this any better than any other staticaly typed language?

replies.author: goobar
replies.text:
That's hard to define exactly as it depends on the definition of "better".  A few things Kotlin has going for it include:

- Really tight integration with IDE tooling as JetBrains develops both the language (with outside help/influence) and the IDE

- Has learned from and incorporated features from languages that come before. Coroutines have strong influence from languages like c# and JavaScript

- In the Android world, it's much more modern than available versions of Java

- Kotlin compiles to JVM, JavaScript, Native (iOS, Mac, Windows, etc) so it can be leveraged in a variety of domains and supports sharing of business logic across platforms

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: I think, in some sense, we will always be looking for another language.  As our understanding of software development, new domains, and computing itself evolves we'll want to improve our tools to go along with it.  I'm sure at some point people thought we wouldn't need another language after Assembly and yet I think most people today are glad we've progressed 😀 . I'm definitely happy to have an alternative to Java 7/8 for Android, and I'm sure at some point I'll be happy to have something in place of Kotlin.

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: @ANKIT SONI I don't think it's a "must" today, but as Google continues to invest in Kotlin the benefits to knowing Kotlin for Android will likely increase.  Since the public decision to go "Kotlin First" is only a few months, there aren't a lot of apis/tools that are only available with Kotlin.  There's nothing wrong with building an Android app with Java, and users won't know the difference.  Ultimately, whatever language allows you to be most productive is probably the best choice.  So if you know Java, I would say keep writing with Java and maybe learn Kotlin as you go until you feel comfortable with it, and then switch to Kotlin.

replies.author: ANKIT SONI
replies.text: @goobar  so its must to learn kotlin..

replies.author: goobar
replies.text: Java is still very viable for Android.  There's no reason you can't still build an app with Java.  However, now that android is "Kotlin First", some of the newest apis will be Kotlin first or perhaps even Kotlin only, so, if you're only using Java some new tools/apis may not be available to you.
